per_prompt_data.prompt: What happened in the incident of the Hindenburg disaster? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
On May 6, 1937, the German airship LZ 129 Hindenburg, carrying 36 passengers and 61 crew, was attempting to dock at Naval Air Station Lakehurst, New Jersey, after a transatlantic flight.

As it neared its mooring mast, the tail section of the hydrogen-filled airship suddenly burst into flames. The fire rapidly engulfed the entire craft within approximately 34 seconds, causing it to crash to the ground.

Tragically, 35 people on board (13 passengers and 22 crew members) and one ground crewman were killed. While the exact cause remains debated, theories range from a static electricity spark igniting leaking hydrogen to sabotage. The disaster marked the end of the airship era for passenger transport.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Can you tell me about the European Investment Bank? Keep your response short with no more than 200 words.
per_prompt_data.side2_response: The European Investment Bank (EIB) is the long‑term lending institution of the European Union, created by the 1957 Treaty of Rome and headquartered in Luxembourg. Owned by EU member states, it is the world’s largest multilateral lender and provides loans, guarantees and advisory services to support EU policy objectives. The EIB finances infrastructure, small and medium enterprises, innovation, digitalisation, regional development and social projects, with a growing focus on climate action and environmental sustainability. It aims to align its operations with the Paris Agreement and target a large share of financing for climate and biodiversity projects. The bank raises funds on capital markets and benefits from a strong credit rating, allowing concessional financing and long maturities. Its work complements EU budgetary tools to mobilise public and private investment across Europe and beyond.
